desc: The software uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

title: CWE-943 - Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Data Query Logic
desc: The application generates a query intended to access or manipulate data in a data store such as a database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that can modify the intended logic of the query.

title: CWE-1004 - Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag
desc:
The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

Background Details:
An HTTP cookie is a small piece of data attributed to a specific website and stored on the user's computer by the user's web browser. This data can be leveraged for a variety of purposes including saving information entered into form fields, recording user activity, and for authentication purposes. Cookies used to save or record information generated by the user are accessed and modified by script code embedded in a web page. While cookies used for authentication are created by the website's server and sent to the user to be attached to future requests. These authentication cookies are often not meant to be accessed by the web page sent to the user, and are instead just supposed to be attached to future requests to verify authentication details.

title: CWE-1007 - Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User
desc: The software displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

title: CWE-1021 - Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames
desc: A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

title: CWE-1022 - Use of Web Link to Untrusted Target with window.opener Access
desc: When a user clicks a link to an external site ("target"), the target="_blank" attribute causes the target site's contents to be opened in a new window or tab, which runs in the same process as the original page. The window.opener object records information about the original page that offered the link.  If an attacker can run script on the target page, then they could read or modify certain properties of the window.opener object, including the location property - even if the original and target site are not the same origin.  An attacker can modify the location property to automatically redirect the user to a malicious site, e.g. as part of a phishing attack. Since this redirect happens in the original window/tab - which is not necessarily visible, since the browser is focusing the display on the new target page - the user might not notice any suspicious redirection.

title: CWE-1023 - Incomplete Comparison with Missing Factors
desc: An incomplete comparison can lead to resultant weaknesses, e.g., by operating on the wrong object or making a security decision without considering a required factor.

title: CWE-1024 - Comparison of Incompatible Types
desc: In languages that are strictly typed but support casting/conversion, such as C or C++, the programmer might assume that casting one entity to the same type as another entity will ensure that the comparison will be performed correctly, but this cannot be guaranteed.  In languages that are not strictly typed, such as PHP or JavaScript, there may be implicit casting/conversion to a type that the programmer is unaware of, causing unexpected results; for example, the string "123" might be converted to a number type.  See examples.

title: CWE-1025 - Comparison Using Wrong Factors
desc: This can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses.  For example, the code might inadvertently compare references to objects, instead of the relevant contents of those objects, causing two "equal" objects to be considered unequal.

title: CWE-1037 - Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code
desc: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

title: CWE-1038 - Insecure Automated Optimizations
desc: The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code, e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance, but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption.

title: CWE-1039 - Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations
desc: The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category, but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different, incorrect concept.

title: CWE-1041 - Use of Redundant Code
desc:
The software has multiple functions, methods, procedures, macros, etc. that
contain the same code.

title: CWE-1042 - Static Member Data Element outside of a Singleton Class Element
desc:
The code contains a member element that is declared as static (but not final), in which
its parent class element 
is not a singleton class - that is, a class element that can be used only once in
the 'to' association of a Create action.

title: CWE-1043 - Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements
desc:
The software uses a data element that has an excessively large
number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects.

title: CWE-1044 - Architecture with Number of Horizontal Layers Outside of Expected Range
desc:
The software's architecture contains too many - or too few -
horizontal layers.

title: CWE-1045 - Parent Class with a Virtual Destructor and a Child Class without a Virtual Destructor
desc: A parent class has a virtual destructor method, but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor.

title: CWE-1046 - Creation of Immutable Text Using String Concatenation
desc: The software creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations.

title: CWE-1047 - Modules with Circular Dependencies
desc: The software contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

title: CWE-1048 - Invokable Control Element with Large Number of Outward Calls
desc:
The code contains callable control elements that
 contain an excessively large number of references to other
 application objects external to the context of the callable,
 i.e. a Fan-Out value that is excessively large.

title: CWE-1049 - Excessive Data Query Operations in a Large Data Table
desc:
The software performs a data query with a large number of joins
and sub-queries on a large data table.

title: CWE-1050 - Excessive Platform Resource Consumption within a Loop
desc:
The software has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or
indirectly consumes platform resources, e.g. messaging, sessions, locks, or file
descriptors.

title: CWE-1051 - Initialization with Hard-Coded Network Resource Configuration Data
desc: The software initializes data using hard-coded values that act as network resource identifiers.

title: CWE-1052 - Excessive Use of Hard-Coded Literals in Initialization
desc:
The software initializes a data element using a hard-coded
literal that is not a simple integer or static constant element.

title: CWE-1053 - Missing Documentation for Design
desc: The product does not have documentation that represents how it is designed.

title: CWE-1054 - Invocation of a Control Element at an Unnecessarily Deep Horizontal Layer
desc:
The code at one architectural layer invokes code that resides
at a deeper layer than the adjacent layer, i.e., the invocation skips at least one
layer, and the invoked code is not part of a vertical utility layer that can be referenced from any horizontal layer.

title: CWE-1055 - Multiple Inheritance from Concrete Classes
desc:
The software contains a class with inheritance from more than
one concrete class.

title: CWE-1056 - Invokable Control Element with Variadic Parameters
desc:
A named-callable or method control element has a signature that
supports a variable (variadic) number of parameters or arguments.

title: CWE-1057 - Data Access Operations Outside of Expected Data Manager Component
desc: The software uses a dedicated, central data manager component as required by design, but it contains code that performs data-access operations that do not use this data manager.

title: CWE-1058 - Invokable Control Element in Multi-Thread Context with non-Final Static Storable or Member Element
desc:
The code contains a function or method that
 operates in a multi-threaded environment but owns an unsafe non-final
 static storable or member data element.

title: CWE-1059 - Incomplete Documentation
desc:
The documentation, whether on paper or in electronic form, does
not contain descriptions of all the relevant elements of the product, such as
its usage, structure, interfaces, design, implementation, configuration,
operation, etc.

title: CWE-1060 - Excessive Number of Inefficient Server-Side Data Accesses
desc: The software performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.

title: CWE-1061 - Insufficient Encapsulation
desc: The software does not sufficiently hide the internal representation and implementation details of data or methods, which might allow external components or modules to modify data unexpectedly, invoke unexpected functionality, or introduce dependencies that the programmer did not intend.

title: CWE-1062 - Parent Class with References to Child Class
desc: The code has a parent class that contains references to a child class, its methods, or its members.

title: CWE-1063 - Creation of Class Instance within a Static Code Block
desc: A static code block creates an instance of a class.

title: CWE-1064 - Invokable Control Element with Signature Containing an Excessive Number of Parameters
desc:
The software contains a function, subroutine, or method whose signature has an unnecessarily large number of
parameters/arguments.

title: CWE-1065 - Runtime Resource Management Control Element in a Component Built to Run on Application Servers
desc: The application uses deployed components from application servers, but it also uses low-level functions/methods for management of resources, instead of the API provided by the application server.

title: CWE-1066 - Missing Serialization Control Element
desc:
The software contains a serializable data element that does not
have an associated serialization method.

title: CWE-1067 - Excessive Execution of Sequential Searches of Data Resource
desc:
The software contains a data query against an SQL table or view
that is configured in a way that does not utilize an index and may cause
sequential searches to be performed.

title: CWE-1068 - Inconsistency Between Implementation and Documented Design
desc:
The implementation of the product is not consistent with the
design as described within the relevant documentation.

title: CWE-1069 - Empty Exception Block
desc: An invokable code block contains an exception handling block that does not contain any code, i.e. is empty.

title: CWE-1070 - Serializable Data Element Containing non-Serializable Item Elements
desc:
The software contains a serializable, storable data element such as a field or member,
but the data element contains member elements that are not
serializable.

title: CWE-1071 - Empty Code Block
desc: The source code contains a block that does not contain any code, i.e., the block is empty.

title: CWE-1072 - Data Resource Access without Use of Connection Pooling
desc:
The software accesses a data resource through a database without using a
connection pooling capability.

title: CWE-1073 - Non-SQL Invokable Control Element with Excessive Number of Data Resource Accesses
desc: The software contains a client with a function or method that contains a large number of data accesses/queries that are sent through a data manager, i.e., does not use efficient database capabilities.

title: CWE-1074 - Class with Excessively Deep Inheritance
desc:
A class has an inheritance level that is too high, i.e., it
has a large number of parent classes.

title: CWE-1075 - Unconditional Control Flow Transfer outside of Switch Block
desc:
The software performs unconditional control transfer (such as a
"goto") in code outside of a branching structure such as a switch
block.

title: CWE-1076 - Insufficient Adherence to Expected Conventions
desc:
The product's architecture, source code, design, documentation,
or other artifact does not follow required conventions.

title: CWE-1077 - Floating Point Comparison with Incorrect Operator
desc:
The code performs a comparison such as an
    equality test between two float (floating point) values, but
    it uses comparison operators that do not account for the
    possibility of loss of precision.

title: CWE-1078 - Inappropriate Source Code Style or Formatting
desc:
The source code does not follow
desired style or formatting for indentation, white
space, comments, etc.

title: CWE-1079 - Parent Class without Virtual Destructor Method
desc: A parent class contains one or more child classes, but the parent class does not have a virtual destructor method.

title: CWE-1080 - Source Code File with Excessive Number of Lines of Code
desc:
A source code file has too many lines of
code.

title: CWE-1082 - Class Instance Self Destruction Control Element
desc: The code contains a class instance that calls the method or function to delete or destroy itself.

title: CWE-1083 - Data Access from Outside Expected Data Manager Component
desc: The software is intended to manage data access through a particular data manager component such as a relational or non-SQL database, but it contains code that performs data access operations without using that component.

title: CWE-1084 - Invokable Control Element with Excessive File or Data Access Operations
desc:
A function or method contains too many
operations that utilize a data manager or file resource.

title: CWE-1085 - Invokable Control Element with Excessive Volume of Commented-out Code
desc:
A function, method, procedure, etc. contains an excessive amount of code that has been
commented out within its body.

title: CWE-1086 - Class with Excessive Number of Child Classes
desc:
A class contains an unnecessarily large number of
children.

title: CWE-1087 - Class with Virtual Method without a Virtual Destructor
desc: A class contains a virtual method, but the method does not have an associated virtual destructor.

title: CWE-1088 - Synchronous Access of Remote Resource without Timeout
desc: The code has a synchronous call to a remote resource, but there is no timeout for the call, or the timeout is set to infinite.

title: CWE-1089 - Large Data Table with Excessive Number of Indices
desc:
The software uses a large data table that contains an excessively large number of
indices.

title: CWE-1090 - Method Containing Access of a Member Element from Another Class
desc:
A method for a class performs an operation that directly
accesses a member element from another class.

title: CWE-1091 - Use of Object without Invoking Destructor Method
desc:
The software contains a method that accesses an object but does not later invoke
the element's associated finalize/destructor method.

title: CWE-1092 - Use of Same Invokable Control Element in Multiple Architectural Layers
desc:
The software uses the same control element across multiple
architectural layers.

title: CWE-1093 - Excessively Complex Data Representation
desc: The software uses an unnecessarily complex internal representation for its data structures or interrelationships between those structures.

title: CWE-1094 - Excessive Index Range Scan for a Data Resource
desc:
The software contains an index range scan for a large data table,
but the scan can cover a large number of rows.

title: CWE-1095 - Loop Condition Value Update within the Loop
desc:
The software uses a loop with a control flow condition based on
a value that is updated within the body of the loop.

title: CWE-1096 - Singleton Class Instance Creation without Proper Locking or Synchronization
desc: The software implements a Singleton design pattern but does not use appropriate locking or other synchronization mechanism to ensure that the singleton class is only instantiated once.

title: CWE-1097 - Persistent Storable Data Element without Associated Comparison Control Element
desc:
The software uses a storable data element that does not have
all of the associated functions or methods that are necessary to support
comparison.

title: CWE-1098 - Data Element containing Pointer Item without Proper Copy Control Element
desc: The code contains a data element with a pointer that does not have an associated copy or constructor method.

title: CWE-1099 - Inconsistent Naming Conventions for Identifiers
desc:
The product's code, documentation, or other artifacts do not
consistently use the same naming conventions for variables, callables, groups of
related callables, I/O capabilities, data types, file names, or similar types of
elements.

title: CWE-1100 - Insufficient Isolation of System-Dependent Functions
desc:
The product or code does not isolate system-dependent
functionality into separate standalone modules.

title: CWE-1101 - Reliance on Runtime Component in Generated Code
desc:
The product uses automatically-generated code that cannot be
executed without a specific runtime support component.

title: CWE-1102 - Reliance on Machine-Dependent Data Representation
desc:
The code uses a data representation that relies on low-level
data representation or constructs that may vary across different processors,
physical machines, OSes, or other physical components.

title: CWE-1103 - Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components
desc:
The product relies on third-party software components that do
not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable
platforms.

title: CWE-1104 - Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components
desc:
The product relies on third-party components that are not
actively supported or maintained by the original developer or a trusted proxy
for the original developer.

title: CWE-1105 - Insufficient Encapsulation of Machine-Dependent Functionality
desc:
The product or code uses machine-dependent functionality, but
it does not sufficiently encapsulate or isolate this functionality from
the rest of the code.

title: CWE-1106 - Insufficient Use of Symbolic Constants
desc:
The source code uses literal constants that may need to change
or evolve over time, instead of using symbolic constants.

title: CWE-1107 - Insufficient Isolation of Symbolic Constant Definitions
desc:
The source code uses symbolic constants, but it does not
sufficiently place the definitions of these constants into a more centralized or
isolated location.

title: CWE-1108 - Excessive Reliance on Global Variables
desc:
The code is structured in a way that relies too much on using
or setting global variables throughout various points in the code, instead of
preserving the associated information in a narrower, more local
context.

title: CWE-1109 - Use of Same Variable for Multiple Purposes
desc:
The code contains a callable, block, or other code element in
which the same variable is used to control more than one unique task or store
more than one instance of data.

title: CWE-1110 - Incomplete Design Documentation
desc:
The product's design documentation does not adequately describe
control flow, data flow, system initialization, relationships between tasks,
components, rationales, or other important aspects of the
design.

title: CWE-1111 - Incomplete I/O Documentation
desc:
The product's documentation does not adequately define inputs,
outputs, or system/software interfaces.

title: CWE-1112 - Incomplete Documentation of Program Execution
desc:
The document does not fully define all mechanisms that are used
to control or influence how product-specific programs are
executed.

title: CWE-1113 - Inappropriate Comment Style
desc:
The source code uses comment styles or formats that are
inconsistent or do not follow expected standards for the
product.

title: CWE-1114 - Inappropriate Whitespace Style
desc:
The source code contains whitespace that is inconsistent across
the code or does not follow expected standards for the
product.

title: CWE-1115 - Source Code Element without Standard Prologue
desc:
The source code contains elements such as source files 
that do not consistently provide a prologue or header that has been
standardized for the project.

title: CWE-1116 - Inaccurate Comments
desc:
The source code contains comments that do not accurately
describe or explain aspects of the portion of the code with which the comment is
associated.

title: CWE-1117 - Callable with Insufficient Behavioral Summary
desc:
The code contains a function or method whose signature and/or associated
inline documentation does not sufficiently describe the callable's inputs, outputs,
side effects, assumptions, or return codes.

title: CWE-1118 - Insufficient Documentation of Error Handling Techniques
desc:
The documentation does not sufficiently describe the techniques
that are used for error handling, exception processing, or similar
mechanisms.

title: CWE-1119 - Excessive Use of Unconditional Branching
desc:
The code uses too many unconditional branches (such as
"goto").

title: CWE-1120 - Excessive Code Complexity
desc:
The code is too complex, as calculated using a well-defined,
quantitative measure.

title: CWE-1121 - Excessive McCabe Cyclomatic Complexity
desc:
The code contains McCabe cyclomatic complexity that exceeds a
desirable maximum.

title: CWE-1122 - Excessive Halstead Complexity
desc:
The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity
measure exceeds a desirable maximum.

title: CWE-1123 - Excessive Use of Self-Modifying Code
desc:
The product uses too much self-modifying
code.

title: CWE-1124 - Excessively Deep Nesting
desc:
The code contains a callable or other code grouping in which
the nesting / branching is too deep.

title: CWE-1125 - Excessive Attack Surface
desc:
The product has an attack surface whose quantitative
measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

title: CWE-1126 - Declaration of Variable with Unnecessarily Wide Scope
desc:
The source code declares a variable in one scope, but the
variable is only used within a narrower scope.

title: CWE-1127 - Compilation with Insufficient Warnings or Errors
desc:
The code is compiled without sufficient warnings enabled, which
may prevent the detection of subtle bugs or quality
issues.

title: CWE-1164 - Irrelevant Code
desc:
The program contains code that is not essential for execution,
 i.e. makes no state changes and has no side effects that alter
 data or control flow, such that removal of the code would have no impact
 to functionality or correctness.

title: CWE-1173 - Improper Use of Validation Framework
desc: Many modern coding languages provide developers with input validation frameworks to make the task of input validation easier and less error-prone. These frameworks will automatically check all input against specified criteria and direct execution to error handlers when invalid input is received. The improper use (i.e., an incorrect implementation or missing altogether) of these frameworks is not directly exploitable, but can lead to an exploitable condition if proper input validation is not performed later in the application. Not using provided input validation frameworks can also hurt the maintainability of code as future developers may not recognize the downstream input validation being used in the place of the validation framework.

title: CWE-1174 - ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Improper Model Validation
desc: The ASP.NET application does not use, or incorrectly uses, the model validation framework.

title: CWE-1176 - Inefficient CPU Computation
desc:
The program performs CPU computations using
 algorithms that are not as efficient as they could be for the
 needs of the developer, i.e., the computations can be
 optimized further.

title: CWE-1177 - Use of Prohibited Code
desc:
The software uses a function, library, or third party component
 that has been explicitly prohibited, whether by the developer or
 the customer.

title: CWE-1187 - DEPRECATED: Use of Uninitialized Resource
desc: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-908. All content has been transferred to CWE-908.

title: CWE-1188 - Insecure Default Initialization of Resource
desc: The software initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

title: CWE-1189 - Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)
desc: The product does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents.

title: CWE-1190 - DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase
desc: The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

title: CWE-1191 - Exposed Chip Debug and Test Interface With Insufficient or Missing Authorization
desc: The chip does not implement or does not correctly check whether users are authorized to access internal registers.

title: CWE-1192 - System-on-Chip (SoC) Using Components without Unique, Immutable Identifiers
desc: The System-on-Chip (SoC) does not have unique, immutable identifiers for each of its components.

title: CWE-1193 - Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control
desc: The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

title: CWE-1209 - Failure to Disable Reserved Bits
desc: The reserved bits in a hardware design are not disabled prior to production. Typically, reserved bits are used for future capabilities and should not support any functional logic in the design.   However, designers might covertly use these bits to debug or further develop new capabilities in production hardware. Adversaries with access to these bits will write to them in hopes of compromising hardware state.

title: CWE-1220 - Insufficient Granularity of Access Control
desc: The product implements access controls via a policy or other feature with the intention to disable or restrict accesses (reads and/or writes) to assets in a system from untrusted agents. However, implemented access controls lack required granularity, which renders the control policy too broad because it allows accesses from unauthorized agents to the security-sensitive assets.

title: CWE-1221 - Incorrect Register Defaults or Module Parameters
desc: Hardware description language code incorrectly defines register defaults or hardware IP parameters to insecure values.

title: CWE-1222 - Insufficient Granularity of Address Regions Protected by Register Locks
desc: The product defines a large address region protected from modification by the same register lock control bit. This results in a conflict between the functional requirement that some addresses need to be writable by software during operation and the security requirement that the system configuration lock bit must be set during the boot process.

title: CWE-1223 - Race Condition for Write-Once Attributes
desc: A write-once register in hardware design is programmable by an untrusted software component earlier than the trusted software component, resulting in a race condition issue.

title: CWE-1224 - Improper Restriction of Write-Once Bit Fields
desc: The hardware design control register "sticky bits" or write-once bit fields are improperly implemented, such that they can be reprogrammed by software.

title: CWE-1229 - Creation of Emergent Resource
desc: The product manages resources or behaves in a way that indirectly creates a new, distinct resource that can be used by attackers in violation of the intended policy.

title: CWE-1230 - Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Metadata
desc: The product prevents direct access to a resource containing sensitive information, but it does not sufficiently limit access to metadata that is derived from the original, sensitive information.

title: CWE-1231 - Improper Implementation of Lock Protection Registers
desc: The product incorrectly implements register lock bit protection features such that protected controls can be programmed even after the lock has been set.

title: CWE-1232 - Improper Lock Behavior After Power State Transition
desc: Register lock bit protection disables changes to system configuration once the bit is set. Some of the protected registers or lock bits become programmable after power state transitions (e.g., Entry and wake from low power sleep modes) causing the system configuration to be changeable.

title: CWE-1233 - Improper Hardware Lock Protection for Security Sensitive Controls
desc: The product implements a register lock bit protection feature that permits security sensitive controls to modify the protected configuration.

title: CWE-1234 - Hardware Internal or Debug Modes Allow Override of Locks
desc: System configuration protection may be bypassed during debug mode.

title: CWE-1235 - Incorrect Use of Autoboxing and Unboxing for Performance Critical Operations
desc: The code uses boxed primitives, which may introduce inefficiencies into performance-critical operations.

title: CWE-1236 - Improper Neutralization of Formula Elements in a CSV File
desc: User-provided data is often saved to traditional databases.  This data can be exported to a CSV file, which allows users to read the data using spreadsheet software such as Excel, Numbers, or Calc.  This software interprets entries beginning with '=' as formulae, which are then executed by the spreadsheet software.  The software's formula language often allows methods to access hyperlinks or the local command line, and frequently allows enough characters to invoke an entire script. Attackers can populate data fields which, when saved to a CSV file, may attempt information exfiltration or other malicious activity when automatically executed by the spreadsheet software.

title: CWE-1239 - Improper Zeroization of Hardware Register
desc: Hardware logic operates on data stored in registers local to the hardware block. Most hardware IPs, including cryptographic accelerators, rely on registers to buffer I/O, store intermediate values, and interface with software. The result of this is that sensitive information, such as passwords or encryption keys, can exist in locations not transparent to the user of the hardware logic. When a different entity obtains access to the IP due to a change in operating mode or conditions, the new entity can extract information belonging to the previous user if no mechanisms are in place to clear register contents. It is important to clear information stored in the hardware if a physical attack on the product is detected, or if the user of the hardware block changes. The process of clearing register contents in a hardware IP is referred to as zeroization in standards for cryptographic hardware modules such as FIPS-140-2 [REF-267].

title: CWE-1240 - Use of a Risky Cryptographic Primitive
desc:
This device implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard or unproven cryptographic primitive.

Background Details:
This issue is even more difficult for hardware-implemented deployment of cryptographic algorithms for several reasons. Because hardware is not patchable as easily as software, any flaw discovered after release and production of the hardware, cannot be fixed in most cases without a recall of the product. Secondly, the hardware product is often expected to work for years, during which time computation power available to the attacker only increases. Therefore, for hardware implementations of cryptographic primitives, it is absolutely essential that only strong, proven cryptographic primitives are used.

title: CWE-1241 - Use of Predictable Algorithm in Random Number Generator
desc: The device uses an algorithm that is predictable and generates a pseudo-random number.

title: CWE-1242 - Inclusion of Undocumented Features or Chicken Bits
desc: The device includes chicken bits or undocumented features that can create entry points for unauthorized actors.

title: CWE-1243 - Sensitive Non-Volatile Information Not Protected During Debug
desc: Access to security-sensitive information stored in fuses is not limited during debug.

title: CWE-1244 - Improper Access to Sensitive Information Using Debug and Test Interfaces
desc: The product's physical debug and test interface protection does not block untrusted agents, resulting in unauthorized access to and potentially control of sensitive assets.

title: CWE-1245 - Improper Finite State Machines (FSMs) in Hardware Logic
desc: Faulty finite state machines (FSMs) in the hardware logic allow an attacker to put the system in an undefined state, to cause a denial of service (DoS) or gain privileges on the victim's system.

title: CWE-1246 - Improper Write Handling in Limited-write Non-Volatile Memories
desc: The product does not implement or incorrectly implements wear leveling operations in limited-write non-volatile memories.

title: CWE-1247 - Missing or Improperly Implemented Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches
desc: The device does not contain or contains improperly implemented circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches and protect sensitive information or software contained on the device.

title: CWE-1248 - Semiconductor Defects in Hardware Logic with Security-Sensitive Implications
desc: The security-sensitive hardware module contains semiconductor defects.

title: CWE-1249 - Application-Level Admin Tool with Inconsistent View of Underlying Operating System
desc: The product provides an application for administrators to manage parts of the underlying operating system, but the application does not accurately identify all of the relevant entities or resources that exist in the OS; that is, the application's model of the OS's state is inconsistent with the OS's actual state.

title: CWE-1250 - Improper Preservation of Consistency Between Independent Representations of Shared State
desc: The product has or supports multiple distributed components or sub-systems that are each required to keep their own local copy of shared data - such as state or cache - but the product does not ensure that all local copies remain consistent with each other.

title: CWE-1251 - Mirrored Regions with Different Values
desc: The product's architecture mirrors regions without ensuring that their contents always stay in sync.

title: CWE-1252 - CPU Hardware Not Configured to Support Exclusivity of Write and Execute Operations
desc: The CPU is not configured to provide hardware support for exclusivity of write and execute operations on memory. This allows an attacker to execute data from all of memory.

title: CWE-1253 - Incorrect Selection of Fuse Values
desc: The logic level used to set a system to a secure state relies on a fuse being unblown. An attacker can set the system to an insecure state merely by blowing the fuse.

title: CWE-1254 - Incorrect Comparison Logic Granularity
desc: The product's comparison logic is performed over a series of steps rather than across the entire string in one operation. If there is a comparison logic failure on one of these steps, the operation may be vulnerable to a timing attack that can result in the interception of the process for nefarious purposes.

title: CWE-1255 - Comparison Logic is Vulnerable to Power Side-Channel Attacks
desc: A device's real time power consumption may be monitored during security token evaluation and the information gleaned may be used to determine the value of the reference token.

title: CWE-1256 - Hardware Features Enable Physical Attacks from Software
desc: Software-controllable device functionality such as power and clock management permits unauthorized modification of memory or register bits.

title: CWE-1257 - Improper Access Control Applied to Mirrored or Aliased Memory Regions
desc: Aliased or mirrored memory regions in hardware designs may have inconsistent read/write permissions enforced by the hardware. A possible result is that an untrusted agent is blocked from accessing a memory region but is not blocked from accessing the corresponding aliased memory region.

title: CWE-1258 - Exposure of Sensitive System Information Due to Uncleared Debug Information
desc: The hardware does not fully clear security-sensitive values, such as keys and intermediate values in cryptographic operations, when debug mode is entered.

title: CWE-1259 - Improper Restriction of Security Token Assignment
desc: Systems-On-A-Chip (Integrated circuits and hardware engines) implement Security Tokens to differentiate and identify which actions originated from which agent. These actions may be one of the directives: 'read', 'write', 'program', 'reset', 'fetch', 'compute', etc. Security Tokens are assigned to every agent in the System that is capable of generating an action or receiving an action from another agent. Multiple Security Tokens may be assigned to an agent and may be unique based on the agent's trust level or allowed privileges. Since the Security Tokens are integral for the maintanence of security in an SoC, they need to be protected properly. A common weakness afflicting Security Tokens is improperly restricting the assignment to trusted components. Consequently, an improperly protected Security Token may be able to be programmed by a malicious agent (i.e., the Security Token is mutable) to spoof the action as if it originated from a trusted agent.

title: CWE-1260 - Improper Handling of Overlap Between Protected Memory Ranges
desc: The product allows address regions to overlap, which can result in the bypassing of intended memory protection.

title: CWE-1261 - Improper Handling of Single Event Upsets
desc: The hardware logic does not effectively handle when single-event upsets (SEUs) occur.

title: CWE-1262 - Register Interface Allows Software Access to Sensitive Data or Security Settings
desc: Memory-mapped registers provide access to hardware functionality from software and if not properly secured can result in loss of confidentiality and integrity.

title: CWE-1263 - Improper Physical Access Control
desc: Sections of a product intended to have restricted access may be inadvertently or intentionally rendered accessible when the implemented physical protections are insufficient. The specific requirements around how robust the design of the physical protection mechanism needs to be depends on the type of product being protected. Selecting the correct physical protection mechanism and properly enforcing it through implementation and manufacturing are critical to the overall physical security of the product.

title: CWE-1264 - Hardware Logic with Insecure De-Synchronization between Control and Data Channels
desc: The hardware logic for error handling and security checks can incorrectly forward data before the security check is complete.

title: CWE-1265 - Unintended Reentrant Invocation of Non-reentrant Code Via Nested Calls
desc: In complex software, a single function call may lead to many different possible code paths, some of which may involve deeply nested calls. It may be difficult to foresee all possible code paths that could emanate from a given function call. In some systems, an external actor can manipulate inputs to the system and thereby achieve a wide range of possible control flows. This is frequently of concern in software that executes script from untrusted sources. Examples of such software are web browsers and PDF readers. A weakness is present when one of the possible code paths resulting from a function call alters program state that the original caller assumes to be unchanged during the call.

title: CWE-1266 - Improper Scrubbing of Sensitive Data from Decommissioned Device
desc: The product does not properly provide a capability for the product administrator to remove sensitive data at the time the product is decommissioned.  A scrubbing capability could be missing, insufficient, or incorrect.

title: CWE-1267 - Policy Uses Obsolete Encoding
desc: The product uses an obsolete encoding mechanism to implement access controls.

title: CWE-1268 - Policy Privileges are not Assigned Consistently Between Control and Data Agents
desc: The product's hardware-enforced access control for a particular resource improperly accounts for privilege discrepancies between control and write policies.

title: CWE-1269 - Product Released in Non-Release Configuration
desc: The product released to market is released in pre-production or manufacturing configuration.

title: CWE-1270 - Generation of Incorrect Security Tokens
desc: The product implements a Security Token mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However, the Security Tokens generated in the system are incorrect.

title: CWE-1271 - Unitialized Value on Reset for Registers Holding Security Settings
desc: Security-critical logic is not set to a known value on reset.

title: CWE-1272 - Sensitive Information Uncleared Before Debug/Power State Transition
desc: Sensitive information may leak as a result of a debug or power state transition when information access restrictions change as a result of the transition.

title: CWE-1273 - Device Unlock Credential Sharing
desc: The credentials necessary for unlocking a device are shared across multiple parties and may expose sensitive information.

title: CWE-1274 - Insufficient Protections on the Volatile Memory Containing Boot Code
desc: The protections on the product's non-volatile memory containing boot code are insufficient to prevent the bypassing of secure boot or the execution of an untrusted, boot code chosen by an adversary.

title: CWE-1275 - Sensitive Cookie with Improper SameSite Attribute
desc: The SameSite attribute controls how cookies are sent for cross-domain requests. This attribute may have three values: 'Lax', 'Strict', or 'None'. If the 'None' value is used, a website may create a cross-domain POST HTTP request to another website, and the browser automatically adds cookies to this request. This may lead to Cross-Site-Request-Forgery (CSRF) attacks if there are no additional protections in place (such as Anti-CSRF tokens).

title: CWE-1276 - Hardware Child Block Incorrectly Connected to Parent System
desc: Signals between a hardware IP and the parent system design are incorrectly connected causing security risks.

title: CWE-1277 - Firmware Not Updateable
desc: The inability to patch the product's firmware means that any weaknesses therein cannot be mitigated through an update. This leaves the system/device open to potential exploitation of the inherent weaknesses. External protective measures and mitigations can be employed to aid in preventing malicious behavior, but the root weakness cannot be corrected.

title: CWE-1278 - Missing Protection Against Hardware Reverse Engineering Using Integrated Circuit (IC) Imaging Techniques
desc: Information stored in hardware may be recovered by an attacker with the capability to capture and analyze images of the integrated circuit using techniques such as scanning electron microscopy.

title: CWE-1279 - Cryptographic Operations are run Before Supporting Units are Ready
desc: Many cryptographic hardware units depend upon other hardware units to supply information to them to produce a securely encrypted result. For example, a cryptographic unit that depends on an external random-number-generator (RNG) unit for entropy must wait until the RNG unit is producing random numbers. If a cryptographic unit retrieves a private encryption key from a fuse unit, the fuse unit must be up and running before a key may be supplied.

title: CWE-1280 - Access Control Check Implemented After Asset is Accessed
desc: A product's hardware-based access control check occurs after the asset has been accessed.

title: CWE-1281 - Sequence of Processor Instructions Leads to Unexpected Behavior (Halt and Catch Fire)
desc: Specific combinations of processor instructions lead to undesirable behavior such as locking the processor until a hard reset performed.

title: CWE-1282 - Assumed-Immutable Data is Stored in Writable Memory
desc: Immutable data, such as a first-stage bootloader, device identifiers, and "write-once" configuration settings are stored in writable memory that can be re-programmed or updated in the field.

title: CWE-1283 - Mutable Attestation or Measurement Reporting Data
desc: The register contents used for attestation or measurement reporting data to verify boot flow are modifiable by an adversary.

title: CWE-1284 - Improper Validation of Specified Quantity in Input
desc: The product receives input that is expected to specify a quantity (such as size or length), but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the quantity has the required properties.

title: CWE-1285 - Improper Validation of Specified Index, Position, or Offset in Input
desc: The product receives input that is expected to specify an index, position, or offset into an indexable resource such as a buffer or file, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the specified index/position/offset has the required properties.

title: CWE-1286 - Improper Validation of Syntactic Correctness of Input
desc: The product receives input that is expected to be well-formed - i.e., to comply with a certain syntax - but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input complies with the syntax.

title: CWE-1287 - Improper Validation of Specified Type of Input
desc: The product receives input that is expected to be of a certain type, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is actually of the expected type.

title: CWE-1288 - Improper Validation of Consistency within Input
desc: The product receives a complex input with multiple elements or fields that must be consistent with each other, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is actually consistent.

title: CWE-1289 - Improper Validation of Unsafe Equivalence in Input
desc: The product receives an input value that is used as a resource identifier or other type of reference, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is equivalent to a potentially-unsafe value.

title: CWE-1290 - Incorrect Decoding of Security Identifiers
desc: The product implements a decoding mechanism to decode certain bus-transaction signals to security identifiers. If the decoding is implemented incorrectly, then untrusted agents can now gain unauthorized access to the asset.

title: CWE-1291 - Public Key Re-Use for Signing both Debug and Production Code
desc: The same public key is used for signing both debug and production code.

title: CWE-1292 - Incorrect Conversion of Security Identifiers
desc: The product implements a conversion mechanism to map certain bus-transaction signals to security identifiers. However, if the conversion is incorrectly implemented, untrusted agents can gain unauthorized access to the asset.

title: CWE-1293 - Missing Source Correlation of Multiple Independent Data
desc: The software relies on one source of data, preventing the ability to detect if an adversary has compromised a data source.

title: CWE-1294 - Insecure Security Identifier Mechanism
desc: The System-on-Chip (SoC) implements a Security Identifier mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However, the Security Identifiers are not correctly implemented.

title: CWE-1295 - Debug Messages Revealing Unnecessary Information
desc: The product fails to adequately prevent the revealing of unnecessary and potentially sensitive system information within debugging messages.

title: CWE-1296 - Incorrect Chaining or Granularity of Debug Components
desc: The product's debug components contain incorrect chaining or granularity of debug components.

title: CWE-1297 - Unprotected Confidential Information on Device is Accessible by OSAT Vendors
desc: The product does not adequately protect confidential information on the device from being accessed by Outsourced Semiconductor Assembly and Test (OSAT) vendors.

title: CWE-1298 - Hardware Logic Contains Race Conditions
desc: A race condition in the hardware logic results in undermining security guarantees of the system.

title: CWE-1299 - Missing Protection Mechanism for Alternate Hardware Interface
desc:
The lack of protections on alternate paths to access
    control-protected assets (such as unprotected shadow registers
    and other external facing unguarded interfaces) allows an
    attacker to bypass existing protections to the asset that are
only performed against the primary path.

title: CWE-1300 - Improper Protection Against Physical Side Channels
desc: The product is missing protections or implements insufficient protections against information leakage through physical channels such as power consumption, electromagnetic emissions (EME), acoustic emissions, or other physical attributes.

title: CWE-1301 - Insufficient or Incomplete Data Removal within Hardware Component
desc: The product's data removal process does not completely delete all data and potentially sensitive information within hardware components.

title: CWE-1302 - Missing Security Identifier
desc: The product implements a security identifier mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. A transaction is sent without a security identifier.

title: CWE-1303 - Non-Transparent Sharing of Microarchitectural Resources
desc: Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g., caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts.

title: CWE-1304 - Improperly Preserved Integrity of Hardware Configuration State During a Power Save/Restore Operation
desc:
The product performs a power save/restore
    operation, but it does not ensure that the integrity of
    the configuration state is maintained and/or verified between
    the beginning and ending of the operation.

title: CWE-1310 - Missing Ability to Patch ROM Code
desc: Missing an ability to patch ROM code may leave a System or System-on-Chip (SoC) in a vulnerable state.

title: CWE-1311 - Improper Translation of Security Attributes by Fabric Bridge
desc: The bridge incorrectly translates security attributes from either trusted to untrusted or from untrusted to trusted when converting from one fabric protocol to another.

title: CWE-1312 - Missing Protection for Mirrored Regions in On-Chip Fabric Firewall
desc: The firewall in an on-chip fabric protects the main addressed region, but it does not protect any mirrored memory or memory-mapped-IO (MMIO) regions.

title: CWE-1313 - Hardware Allows Activation of Test or Debug Logic at Runtime
desc: During runtime, the hardware allows for test or debug logic (feature) to be activated, which allows for changing the state of the hardware. This feature can alter the intended behavior of the system and allow for alteration and leakage of sensitive data by an adversary.

title: CWE-1314 - Missing Write Protection for Parametric Data Values
desc: The device does not write-protect the parametric data values for sensors that scale the sensor value, allowing untrusted software to manipulate the apparent result and potentially damage hardware or cause operational failure.

title: CWE-1315 - Improper Setting of Bus Controlling Capability in Fabric End-point
desc: The bus controller enables bits in the fabric end-point to allow responder devices to control transactions on the fabric.

title: CWE-1316 - Fabric-Address Map Allows Programming of Unwarranted Overlaps of Protected and Unprotected Ranges
desc: The address map of the on-chip fabric has protected and unprotected regions overlapping, allowing an attacker to bypass access control to the overlapping portion of the protected region.

title: CWE-1317 - Missing Security Checks in Fabric Bridge
desc: A bridge that is connected to a fabric without security features forwards transactions to the slave without checking the privilege level of the master.  Similarly, it does not check the hardware identity of the transaction received from the slave interface of the bridge.

title: CWE-1318 - Missing Support for Security Features in On-chip Fabrics or Buses
desc: On-chip fabrics or buses either do not support or are not configured to support privilege separation or other security features, such as access control.

title: CWE-1319 - Improper Protection against Electromagnetic Fault Injection (EM-FI)
desc: The device is susceptible to electromagnetic fault injection attacks, causing device internal information to be compromised or security mechanisms to be bypassed.

title: CWE-1320 - Improper Protection for Out of Bounds Signal Level Alerts
desc: Untrusted agents can disable alerts about signal conditions exceeding limits or the response mechanism that handles such alerts.

title: CWE-1321 - Improperly Controlled Modification of Object Prototype Attributes ('Prototype Pollution')
desc: The software receives input from an upstream component that specifies attributes that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control modifications of attributes of the object prototype.

title: CWE-1322 - Use of Blocking Code in Single-threaded, Non-blocking Context
desc:
The product uses a non-blocking model that relies on a single threaded process
for features such as scalability, but it contains code that can block when it is invoked.

title: CWE-1323 - Improper Management of Sensitive Trace Data
desc:
Trace data collected from several sources on the
    System-on-Chip (SoC) is stored in unprotected locations or
    transported to untrusted agents.

title: CWE-1324 - Sensitive Information Accessible by Physical Probing of JTAG Interface
desc:
Sensitive information in clear text on the JTAG
    interface may be examined by an eavesdropper, e.g.
    by placing a probe device on the interface such as a logic
    analyzer, or a corresponding software technique.

title: CWE-1325 - Improperly Controlled Sequential Memory Allocation
desc: The product manages a group of objects or resources and performs a separate memory allocation for each object, but it does not properly limit the total amount of memory that is consumed by all of the combined objects.

title: CWE-1326 - Missing Immutable Root of Trust in Hardware
desc: A missing immutable root of trust in the hardware results in the ability to bypass secure boot or execute untrusted or adversarial boot code.

title: CWE-1327 - Binding to an Unrestricted IP Address
desc: The product assigns the address 0.0.0.0 for a database server, a cloud service/instance, or any computing resource that communicates remotely.

title: CWE-1328 - Security Version Number Mutable to Older Versions
desc: Security-version number in hardware is mutable, resulting in the ability to downgrade (roll-back) the boot firmware to vulnerable code versions.

title: CWE-1329 - Reliance on Component That is Not Updateable
desc: The product contains a component that cannot be updated or patched in order to remove vulnerabilities or significant bugs.

title: CWE-1330 - Remanent Data Readable after Memory Erase
desc: Confidential information stored in memory circuits is readable or recoverable after being cleared or erased.

title: CWE-1331 - Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip
desc: The product does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents, creating timing channels.

title: CWE-1332 - Insufficient Protection Against Instruction Skipping Via Fault Injection
desc:
The device is missing or incorrectly
    implements circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate CPU
    instruction skips that can be caused by fault injection.

title: CWE-1334 - Unauthorized Error Injection Can Degrade Hardware Redundancy
desc: An unauthorized agent can inject errors into a redundant block to deprive the system of redundancy or put the system in a degraded operating mode.

title: CWE-1338 - Improper Protections Against Hardware Overheating
desc: A hardware device is missing or has inadequate protection features to prevent overheating.
